reviewText:
A Prequel to Labyronia RPG
This game is about exploring your locations, talking to NPC's, gathering evidences, finding and using items to unlock new and previously locked rooms and area.

Pros:

• Windir's story.
• Crime investigation.
• Plot is really good.


Cons:

• Really hard puzzles & quests. (time-consuming if you don't know what you're doing.)
• No XP system.
• Annoying obstacles.

reviewText:
I've played many many RPGs in my day. Starting with Wizardry games on the PC when I was young and onto Final Fantasy, playing the newer ones as they came out. I was a PlayStation girl so I played the Personas, Xenogears, Grandias, Shadow Hearts - okay, listing them all would take too long and is off the topic. But I want you to know how well-versed I am in this genre. :)

Legend of Mysteria is the first RPG I've played on Steam that was obviously made using one of the generic RPGmakers and isn't a big hit" game. I thought I'd give something different a chance. And I'm extremely glad I did.

Now
date: it's listed as a turn-based RPG but it's really all about an involving story where you do some serious detective work. In all the hours I played
recommended: I fought only a little over 10 battles - half of those
hoursPlayed: bosses. There is no leveling in this game whatsoever. You have to find different equipment to bolster your stats. And you play as a mage so the trick is figuring out what your enemy is weak against and then finding a staff or accessories that allow you to cast the elemental spell that will annihilate your target the quickest.\n\nThe meat of the game is interviewing everyone you can. Everyone thinks you're a murderer so you have to find the real culprit and clear your name. Of course
voteText: being that people view you as a killer
helpfulPercent: you must disguise yourself. You begin in a tower full of all different types of mages. You'll need to switch robes often to fit in with whatever group you're spying on. You also get different dialog choices here and there so think carefully before answering. Searching everywhere and everything is a must since you need those different colored robes
votesHelpful: and reading notes and diaries on all the mages will help you find clues and point you towards those who might be willing to help you in your cause.\n\nI would say this game is difficult. The times I had to turn to a walkthrough
votesTotal: I would sit there reading it thinking "who in the world would know this is what you're supposed to do?" But the story was so interesting that I had to see it to its end. What you do during the entire game affects what will happen at the very end. It's just very neat.\n\nSo in conclusion
votesFunny: this is not your typical RPG. It's frustrating at times and... no leveling? I'm  a girl who loves to level for hours so I can swat the last boss like a bug. In this game
commentsCount: I actually had to strategize my fights and manage my healing potions with care. :p  However
column16: I loved Legend of Mysteria. I was never bored
column17: the characters were interesting and detailed
column18: and I really approved of the music selections they chose from the RPGmaker. The fact that I'm even writing this review at all says a lot because I don't really want to be doing this. I want to be playing! I just wanted you to know how much fun I had with this unique adventure. :)"

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I was given a key for this game for free.

Full Review (for my original Quick First Look just scroll down):

Legend of Mysteria is a spin-off from the Labyronia RPG series and story wise a prequel. While there are a lot of familiar characters and the main area of the game is the so called Mysteria Tower, the story can be enjoyed on it's own, without any prior knowledge. However if you have played Labyronia RPG 1 and 2, Legend of Mysteria will give some nice additional insights. The main storyline, the murder of a high rank mage called Dinyon and Windir (the player character) trying to clear his name, while being accused of being the man behind the dirty deed, is a very well put together detective story that will keep you guessing until pretty late who the true culprit is.

As I have already said in my First Look, gameplay wise is where the biggest different lies between Legend of Mysteria and the original Labyronia RPG games. While all 3 titles share their RPG Maker VX Ace foundation, the later are more traditional CRPG games with a quite a heavy focus on battles. Legend of Mysteria on the other hand plays more like a classic Point & Click adventure with hardly any battles at all and even then, there is no real RPG style character progression, XP system etc. This game is about exploring your locations, talking to NPC, gathering evidence, finding and using items to unlock new and previously locked rooms and areas. At this point it needs to be noted that even though I have played a lot of adventures in my gaming career (including most LucasArts Games and even more Sierra Games), I did get stuck quite a lot. This is not due to strange tasks to be done, but rather the fact the due to the absence of a quest log, the player should really start writing (I mean really writing with pen & paper!!) down notes. Thankfully to a kind player, there is a full walkthrough in the community guides section!

In conclusion I can highly recommend this game to both fans of the series for the insight it shares to the lore of Labyronia, as well as to everbody looking for a RPG Maker game that doesn't follow the usual steps a RPG Maker game does take!

-------------------

Quick First Look:

Legend of Mysteria RPG is a spin-off from the Labyronia RPG series; actually according to the title screen it should be called Labyronia Tales Legend of Mysteria". Hence anybody who is familiar with the main series

hoursPlayed: only at a different time and with new content. This should not scare of newcomers

helpfulPercent: at least from what I have seen so far. It actually feels way more like a classic adventure game with RPG elements. In the beginning the player character
votesTotal: gets innocently accused of attacking and possibly murdering another Mage called Dinyon. Now it is time to find the real culprit and clear Windir's name. This all happens in traditional adventure game style
commentsCount: doing favors for them and finding ways to access new areas.\nWhat about the battles
column16: you might be asking by now? There are battles
column18: it actually will take some time until you will have your first encounters. Despite appearing to be easier now
column19: simple attack spamming still won't get you anywhere - just don't forget that Windir is a mage!\n\nIn conclusion I can easily recommend this game to fans of Labyronia RPG
column21: even though it kinda feels different now. There are many characters appearing from the main series as well as well-known locations featuring additional content (new areas). However this should not turn off newcomers
column22: as no prior knowledge is required to make sense of what is going on.\n\nNOTE: I will update this quick first look with a full fledged review

reviewText:
I wanted to complete Labyronia 1 & 2 before I review this, but now that I have I think it's about time I reviewed Legend of Mysteria.


First off I'm not a big fan of rpg games, I haven't played them a whole lot like I play racing games, or first person games. Yet, I saw the game was on sale for 51 cents, and I thought, Why not?"

I must say I am glad I spent the $.51 on this game. I haven't had much fun playing rpg games in a long time until I tried this and the Labyronia series. The soundtrack of the game is probably one of my favorites out of most games I've played. The battles with enemies could be a bit challenging
date: but nonetheless the gameplay did not fail to make up for it. It was definitely difficult playing the game since it required so much I had to use use walkthroughs like guides or videos to help me out for the rest of the game. I still couldn't complain though
recommended: I enjoyed the many puzzles and clues throughout the game.\n\nThere's a lot of questions I have IF this happened before Labyronia since Windir and Triste marry each other and have a child
voteText: you find out Arres is their son. Yet the release dates of the games throw me off so I'm not sure if that speculation would be valid enough to say that Legend of Mysteria happened before Labyronia. Either way
helpfulPercent: much props to the developers of this game.\n\nThe only thing I would suggest is to fix the brightness of the game. Besides that
votesTotal: and I'd suggest this to anyone who are willing to play rpg games and enjoy long stories."

reviewText: Recently I've played a decent amount of RPG games and I have to say that I am starting to like them more and more. Got Legend of Mysteria" in a bundle and payed about 10-15 cents for it. You can literally get more than that by selling the cards that drop when you play the game
recommended: unlike some other cheap games that I've played this is one of the best. As you can see it took me a bit more than 8 hours to finish the game and get all the achievements. Although It can be done faster I followed a step-by-step walkthrough and even so it took that long. I mentioned this in another review but I will say it again: A guy had written in a review that for every 1 euro game he/she expects to get at least 1 hour worth of gameplay. So if we follow this logic I got the game almost free and I spent 8 hours playing it meaning the price it has is pretty good

reviewText:
Disclosure: Received a review copy.

Labyronia part 3 is up to testing after getting a review key and to my great surprise it is not actually a real sequel to the first two games but instead a prequel to the events to come in part 1 and 2. In addition the game type has changed from typical JRPG style adventure to a more 'detective story' type of gameplay where Windir from earlier games is the protagonist who tries to solve a murder taking place in a mage school and clear his name as he is framed for the murder.

After some 6h i must say the game is of same high quality as the previous games in the series. i.e. what it lacks in original art and assets it gains in good design. I guess you could say the dev did not spend his time at the art drawing board but instead did good work on the design board and it really shows. Lots of details and well tested gameplay as i have not seen any bugs yet.

As it looks now Labyronia games are some of the best what this old game engine can offer and therefore a warm recommendation to anyone who wants good games for cheap with high production values.

reviewText:
I had hopes for this game since it's opening premise is interesting enough and though its made in the RPG maker the maps and items for the game where customized enought and look nice, buuuuut...

The game becomes a snore fest after a couple of hours, at the start it's interesting enough to read all the documents and uncover clues to find out who framed you, but then it becomes a nightmare of finding objects and find where you are supposed to use them, some of them I have no idea how you where supposed to find out the solution without a walkthough.

There is not nearly enough tips in the game as of how to use certain items, for example, how are you supposed to know Djinni is able to spy on people if you put its crystal in a nearby cup" or "bucket" ? How are you supposed to know which object corresponds to which crystal in the corridor of elements to get the tome of elements?

Horrid nightmarish time waster. Get the cards and get out."

reviewText:
Review Upon Legend Of Mysteria RPG
Written by Rias Gremory

ProsThis game isn't really my type of game, but I enjoyed playing the first couple of 'hours' of the game, I have seen not really any problems, there are not really many tips, so you will have to find your own, The art style is very dark and 'pixely' but I can see through that and enjoy the game play, the HUD is easy to use and extremely simple, like no joke. The game isn't all that fast paced, but it has small animal fights like pokemon, (seen in the trailer on steam store) of which I do feel is a bit cheap of them to do, but that is their game...

ConsI was unable to get the feel of the game, even after playing like 16 hours of it. I found it hard to follow the story due to the lack of information on the steam store page, and really just all over the internet. I seemed to run really fast when going sideways as well, I noticed the fact that you can go faster going left or right on your keyboard than going forward or backwards (evening this out would make a heavy difference. Overall I did find a lot of the start to be a bit silly, and not really immersive, but I would still play the game.

Overall ReviewGiving the fact that the game lacks in the immersive story telling, and the fact that it is just like a lot of other cheap basic RPG games, I would still find a way for me to play it, and have fun, whether this being hacking (Item mods) or possibly even messing with game files, I would be able to spend my time playing this sky view RPG game. I would not reccomend this game to those who hate story lacking games, but if you wish to try it, then feel free. There is not really much I can say about this game, as I have not really completed it.

Extra InformationDeveloper(s): Labyrinthine
Publisher(s): EQ Games
Platform(s): Windows
Release Date: October 9th 2015

Source(s)
Personal Experience
Steam Store Page
Google

Written for 11th Floor 11th Floor Group

reviewText: Purchased the Labyronia Bundle for 2.99. Finished Legend of Mysteria and would've more than paid double just for the one game. The graphics are very Final Fantasy Tactics, there are about five, maybe, actual battles that are turn based and easily won. This game is much more about figuring out the palace/tower/race intrigue than duking it out. For the entire game you HAVE TO PAY ATTENTION! Read everything, notice the symbols, things that look like decoration probably aren't, if you have looked in every single goblet and turned up empty, the one you don't check will be the one you need. The puzzles give you everything you need - if you can't figure it out with what you've got, go back and see what you missed picking up.

reviewText:
Being the prequel to Labyonia I thought it was going to be action packed, but NOPE. Puzzles, puzzles and even more puzzles!

Pros:
- Backstory to Labyonia

Cons:
- It's a puzzle game! Nothing like Labyonia or Labyonia II at all.
- Not enough action. Nothing like the two games it is based off of.
- Having to re-do the same maze path multiple times just to get from point A to point B
- No side-quests
- Under 5 hours (compared to Labyonia which was 15 hours and Labyonia II which was 10 hours)

reviewText: MURDER! in Labyronia!? in Mysteria tower, Dinyon the head of council has been murderd, shot by an arrow during a meeting of the mages !( rather personal if you ask me) Windir our favorite Labyronia mage is back, but hes been framed for the murder. In this Clue like game, discover the vile plot and who the  true killer is, by escaping your prison and scouring the Mysteria tower for clues and suspects. A great change of pace from the RPG maker games , this is one for the mystery Scooby Doo fans. Very much did I actually want to see how everything plays out . Collecting and pretty much on ''high alert'' about everything, do you go through the game trying to figure out what happend. Picking up and finding items and when/ where to use them is key to the game.  ''Does that plant pot over there have a key hidden in it?''  kinda thing.You pick up some comrades and friends ( even a lil dragon) and try to clear Windir's name. A smart gameplay too with disguises to get by and trick guards and fellow mages. Try if you like the Labyronia games and want to try a rather well done JRPG.

reviewText: To all you JRPG Fans out here, I know this Isn't Chrono Trigger level of quality, but the problem its not that this is an RPG Maker Game, The problem is the developement felt very lazy thus this very low price It's very short and even still will make you feel bored from the start of the game. It Also runs poorly.\n\nDear developers please don't see the JRPG genre as a effortless cash-in, we very much expect a story rich indie rpg game with some new mechanics.  Pick this up only for the steam trading cards, it's not really worth playing it unless only for the achievements.

reviewText:
I have recieved this game for free as part of a promotion for the game. Regardless of whether I paid for it or not, I remain unbiased in all of my reviews. My reviews reflect my opinion, and my opinion only.

Something something powerful crystal, something something dark lord, something something RPG Maker.

I want to become engrossed in these games, I really do, but it's really hard to do when you see recycled materials used over and over again. I imagine it's really fun when you get into it, but I just done care what's happening anymore. I can't become immersed when I'm staring at the same scene with walls of text explaining the back story. If I wanted to play a game based on a light novel I would just read the novel. I couldn't even get into the combat, I was lost at the beginning. The music is pretty good though, from what I heard, but it was awkwardly misplaced...

It's like, two dollars though. That's like, the price of a soda, or a couple hamburgers from the dollar menu, so save yourself the diabetes and heart disease, try one of these things out and you'll see what I mean.

reviewText:
Another great addition to the Labyronia series and it is enjoyable to see parts of the world before the events of the first game transpired.  Though I enjoyed the plots of the first and second Labyronia RPG better, this story is not bad and it is neat to see the game move away from a combat focus by removing the leveling system.

I love the characters and felt a deeper attachment to them, especially with the knowledge of what will happen, and greatly recommend that if you are interested in playing this game than play Labyronia RPG 1 and 2 first.  That way, I believe, you’ll have a deeper interest and better understanding of the world and those in it.

reviewText: A more interesting RPG where you search for clues and do favors for others not because you are going for the good ending" but because you are searching for the actual culprit and you have to clear your name.\nThis one has more interesting puzzles and some situations turn quite interesting. A little touch of Sherlock Holmes (a little as I said) give this game a nice atmosphere and a more interesting story than the classic save the world RPG."

reviewText: I honestly did not finish this game.  However I respect it for what it does.  It does alright for what it is, and it is a nice twist on your normal RPGMaker fare.  I should have known better than to buy this since I get bored easily by puzzles.

reviewText: I want to preface with the fact that this isn't really my kind of game. I played it as long as I did because I wanted specifically to give it a review. Legend of Mysteria is a really charming game, and it did a really good job of reminding me of classic similar games without beating me over the head with it. In the five minutes I played, I really liked the soundtrack, and the controls were fluid enough. Basically, if you like games similar to this, you could do a lot worse than to play Legend of Mysteria.

reviewText:
It's a neat game that'll keep you entertained for several hours, at least if you play without using guides.
Really tests your memory. The story is also kind of cute, I suppose.

Would give it a 10/10 considering that it did cost me 0.24 euro, worth buying!

reviewText: I've played several of these RPGmaker-type games, and this is one of my favourites.\n\nSolid story, challenging puzzles and very little of the turn-based combat that you normally find in this type of game (which for me is a good thing). While some of the obstacles can be irritating and it's not always easy to find the right piece of information and where to use it, I thoroughly enjoyed this game and would definitely recommend it, especially considering how cheap it is.
